docs.lead_paragraph: Eating fish regularly late in pregnancy may speed fetal growth, perhaps lowering the risk of having a low-birth-weight baby, according to a new study in The Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. The report is based on a survey of more than 11,500 pregnant women in southwest England. The researchers, from the University of Bristol, said the benefits from eating fish late in pregnancy might have been tied to the omega-3 fatty acids found in fish.
docs.abstract: Dr Imogen Rogers of University of Bristol leads study linking birth weights of newborns and eating fish late in pregnancy; findings, published in Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, shows that women who consumed most fish after 32 weeks of pregnancy had lowest risk of delivering low-weight baby; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Eating fish regularly late in pregnancy may speed fetal growth, perhaps lowering the risk of having a low-birth-weight baby, according to a new study in The Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health.    The report is based on a survey of more than...

docs.lead_paragraph: As bacteria have grown increasingly resistant to standard antibiotics, scientists have begun a desperate search for alternatives to the drugs. In one promising approach, they are trying to harness viruses that naturally evolved to prey on harmful bacteria and to use them as weapons for staving off intruders. That may sound like a new idea, but it is a revival of an ancient remedy. Therapies that use bacteria-eating viruses -- bacteriophages, or just phage for short -- have been part of traditional cures for centuries in India, and they have been practiced in the former Soviet Union for decades.

headline.main: Revival of an Old Cure: Bacteria-Eating Viruses

docs.abstract: Drug companies, looking for alternatives to antibiotics, develop bacteriophages, viruses designed to prey on harmful bacteria; GangaGen, company based in San Franscico and Bangalore, plans human trials in Indian hospitals for strain of virus that attacks staph bacteria; GangaGen founder Dr Janakiraman Ramachandran explains that although bacteriophages can typically replicate in human body and potentially become toxic, company has developed first virus that does not risk explosion in human host; history of bacteriophages discussed (M)
docs.snippet: As bacteria have grown increasingly resistant to standard antibiotics, scientists have begun a desperate search for alternatives to the drugs. In one promising approach, they are trying to harness viruses that naturally evolved to prey on harmful...

docs.lead_paragraph: As a recovering hypochondriac who is accident prone, I have a certain amount of experience with emergency medicine in the United States. I'm adept at filling out forms. I know how to contain my envy of other patients who are bleeding more than I am and will therefore be seen first. And I know, for an absolute certainty, that no matter how much my knee or leg or ankle hurts, X-rays will reveal that I did not break anything.

headline.main: Watch Your Fingers! Medical Misadventures Of a Diver in Belize

docs.abstract: James Gorman Cases article discusses emergency medical treatment he received while visiting Belize; compares service and cost of treatment with same care in United States; holds that medical care in Belize is good dollar value; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: As a recovering hypochondriac who is accident prone, I have a certain amount of experience with emergency medicine in the United States.    I'm adept at filling out forms. I know how to contain my envy of other patients who are bleeding more than I...

docs.lead_paragraph: Macie Mull was 82 and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for more than a decade when she developed pneumonia. Her nursing home rushed her to the hospital where she spent the night, receiving intravenous antibiotics. The next day she was back at the nursing home, more confused than ever. Now she was choking on her puréed food; eating was becoming impossible. And so, one Sunday afternoon, the administrators of her nursing home in Hickory, N.C., asked Mrs. Mull's daughter what to do: Did she want a feeding tube inserted? At that point, Mrs. Mull muttered only a few random words and could no longer recognize her daughter. The feeding tube would almost certainly prolong her life, but was it worth it?

headline.main: When Alzheimer's Steals the Mind, How Aggressively to Treat the Body?

docs.abstract: Experts and family members debate how agressively patients with late-stage Alzheimer's should be treated; Dr Susan Mitchell of Harvard University and Hebrew Rehabilitation Home for Aged studied nursing home patients and found late-stage Alzheimer's patients often receive more aggressive medical treatment than other terminal patients near death; cost of treatments, pain for patient and impact of prolonged procedures figure into decision whether to intervene with feeding tubes and intravenous fluids or allow patient to die; Dr Douglas Nelson, Hickory, North Carolina, geriatrician, wrote position paper, which was unanimously passed by state medical society and discourages use of feeding tube for late-stage Alzheimer's patients, but admits many families are unable to let aged relative die; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A health-conscious woman asked me the other day whether she should be taking magnesium with her calcium. I thought not, but that was before I had examined the many studies defining the role of this too-often-ignored mineral nutrient. Magnesium is important to nearly every function and tissue in the body, from the heart to the bones and nearly everything in between. It plays a critical role in a vast array of acute and chronic diseases. Some 350 enzyme functions depend on it, including the enzyme that generates energy for every cell in the body.

headline.main: A Dietary Mineral You Need (and Probably Didn't Know It)

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses often overlooked mineral nutrient magnesium; Dr Mildred S Seelig, retired University of North Carolina professor and author of The Magnesium Factor, explains disorders that can cause magnesium deficiency and role of magnesium in overall health; suggests two to one ratio of calcium to magnesium; dietary sources of magnesium discussed; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the SARS epidemic ended last July, experts were concerned that it would come back from wherever it hid in nature. But officials of the World Health Organization were just as worried about a new epidemic emerging from a SARS sample that escaped from one of the many laboratories working with it. Those fears were confirmed by two accidents in Singapore and Taiwan in August and December.

headline.main: SARS's Second Act, Playing in Laboratories

docs.abstract: SARS, which reached epidemic proportions in 2003, has not recurred in natural form as feared; virus has instead become laboratory-borne illness with outbreaks at facilities in Singapore, Taiwan and China; most recent outbreak in China resulted in seven infections and death of laboratory worker at China's Centers for Disease Control's Institute of Virology; Australian virologist John MacKenzie, who visited Beijing lab, holds that infection should have been identified sooner; holds that training for lab workers needs to be evaluated citing that three out of four individuals who were infected from direct lab contact with SARS were students; graph (M)
docs.snippet: When the SARS epidemic ended last July, experts were concerned that it would come back from wherever it hid in nature. But officials of the World Health Organization were just as worried about a new epidemic emerging from a SARS sample that escaped...

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of Americans say they brush their teeth after every meal, but when it comes to overall dental hygiene, women clearly outpace men, a new survey has found. The survey, conducted for the American Dental Association, found that almost one-fourth of the people questioned said they brushed after every meal -- more than twice the number reported in a survey six years earlier.

headline.main: A Gender Gap in Dental Hygiene

docs.abstract: American Dental Assn survey shows that women are more diligent at taking care of their teeth; women brush more frequently and see dentist more consistently; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A growing number of Americans say they brush their teeth after every meal, but when it comes to overall dental hygiene, women clearly outpace men, a new survey has found.    The survey, conducted for the American Dental Association, found that almost...

docs.lead_paragraph: For people older than 65, the effects of alcohol may be worsened by medications. Even if a person is not taking any medications, experts suggest that older adults limit alcohol consumption to one drink a day. One drink is defined as 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine or 1 1/2 ounces of hard liquor.

headline.main: Help for Older People With Alcohol Problems

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Department's Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration puts out additional information on alcohol and its effects on seniors; suggests that older adults consume only one drink per day; warning signs of alcohol abuse given (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you are unfortunate enough to come down with ''swimmer's itch,'' a parasite-caused irritation common to people in some lake areas, there is not much to do but wait -- and try not to scratch. But a new study suggests that swimmers can reduce the chances of becoming infected by paying attention to water depths and prevailing winds. The report appears in the current issue of The American Journal of Public Health.
docs.abstract: Dr Lois M Berbrugge of University of Michigan leads study on skin condition called swimmer's itch; study show that condition is more likely to occur in shallow water on fresh water lake with onshore winds; findings are published in American Journal of Public Health; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: If you are unfortunate enough to come down with ''swimmer's itch,'' a parasite-caused irritation common to people in some lake areas, there is not much to do but wait -- and try not to scratch.    But a new study suggests that swimmers can reduce the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ed's beverage of choice was Scotch. He drank it hard for 50 years, but his drinking, he said, never interfered with his work as a securities analyst on Wall Street. Seven years ago, Ed, who insisted that his surname not be printed, retired.

headline.main: When Retirement Leaves an Emptiness, Some Fill It With Alcohol

docs.abstract: Older Americans have been found to be at increased risk of alcohol abuse in part because as body ages effects of alcohol can be amplified; medications being taken can also add to problem; Carol Colleran, Hazelden Foundation older adult services director, holds that retirees sometimes feel disconnected and useless without consistency of work and daily decision-making; treatment programs geared for seniors are very successful and older adults appear more receptive to appropriate counseling; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Ed's beverage of choice was Scotch. He drank it hard for 50 years, but his drinking, he said, never interfered with his work as a securities analyst on Wall Street.    Seven years ago, Ed, who insisted that his surname not be printed, retired.
